title: 111_s1544
content: The Act may be cited as the "Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation Governance Improvement Act of 2009". It pertains to the Board of Directors of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation. The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation Governance Improvement Act of 2009 amends the composition of the board of directors to include representatives from the Treasury, Labor, Commerce, employers with defined benefit plans, organized labor, employees, and two other members appointed by the President with Senate approval. The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation Governance Improvement Act of 2009 amends the board of directors composition to include representatives from various sectors, with restrictions on political party affiliation and financial interests. Members serve for 4 years, with different terms based on their description under specific subparagraphs. The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation Governance Improvement Act of 2009 amends the board of directors composition to include representatives from various sectors. Members serve without compensation but are reimbursed for expenses. Each member designates a voting representative, and different terms apply based on their description under specific subparagraphs. The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation Governance Improvement Act of 2009 amends the board of directors composition, with members compensated at a rate not exceeding GS-18 pay. The Secretary of Labor chairs the board, the President designates a vice-chairman, and the Inspector General reports to the corporation. The Inspector General of the corporation reports to the board of directors at least twice a year, providing findings on monitoring and operations. The General Counsel serves as the board's secretary, advises as needed, and handles all legal matters except those related to the Inspector General's office. The Office of Inspector General and its legal counsel are independent of the corporation's management. The board of directors must meet at least 4 times a year with a quorum of 5 members, including a joint meeting with the advisory committee. The chairman of the board must make meeting information available. The chairman of the board must make meeting minutes public unless designated as closed for confidential discussions. The advisory committee can address specified issues and other relevant matters as determined appropriate. The Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to require at least one joint meeting of the advisory committee with the board of directors each year. SEC. 3. AVOIDING CONFLICTS OF INTEREST. The Director and board members must agree to recuse themselves from activities with potential conflicts of interest. SEC. 4. SENSE OF CONGRESS. The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation should form committees like an audit and investment committee to enhance effectiveness. Additionally, a risk management position should be established to evaluate and mitigate potential risks.
